ANNO REGNI

GEORGII ILL

Britanniarum Regis, QUADRAGESIMO NONO.

At the Parliament begun and holden at Westminster, the Twenty-second Day of June, Anno Domini 1807, in the Forty-seventh Year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lord GEORGE the Third, by the Grace of God, of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith:

And from thence continued, by several Prorogations, to the Nineteenth Day of January 1809, being the THIRD SESSION of the FOURTH PARLIAMENT of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

LONDON:

Printed by George Eyre and Andrew Strahan, Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty. 1809.

Cap. i.

An Act for continuing the Term and Powers of several Acts passed for repairing the Harbour and Quay of JVatchett, in the County of Somerset.

[2 2d February 1809.]

WHEREAS by an Act passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign of

her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, An Act for repairing 6 Anne' c- 8. the Harbour and Key of Watchet, in the County of Somerset, it was enacted, That from and after the Five and Twentieth Day of March One thousand seven hundred and eight, for the Term of One and Twenty Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament, there should be paid the several Rates and Duties in the said Act mentioned and expressed, for all Goods and Merchandizes exported, shipped, or laden or discharged at or within the said Harbour or Key, and also the several Duties'of Tonnage and Keelage for Ships, Hoys, Barks, and Vessels, which during the said Term should come into the said Harbour for Security and Preservation (the said Port or Harbour not being their discharging Port); and after the Expiration of the said Term of One and Twenty Years, One Half of the said Rates and Duties by the said Act granted on the several Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned was to continue to be collected for ever, in order for the raising a sufficient Stock and Supply lor keeping the said Harbour and Key in good Repair: And whereas by a Clause in another Act, passed in the Tenth Year of her said late Majesty’s Reign, intituled. An Act for prolonging the Term for Payment of certain 10 An. e. 14. Duties granted by an Act, made in the Twelfth and Thirteenth Tears of his [.hoc. 1$ Per.] A 2 late

First, intituled, An Act for continuing the Duties granted by several Acts made in the Sixth and Tenth Tears of her late Majesty’s Reign, for repairing the Harbour and Key of Watchett in the County of Somerset, the several Rates and Duties by the said Act passed in the Sixth Year of her said late Majesty’s Reign, granted and made payable for the said Term of Twenty-one Years, were from and after the Expiration of the said Term, charged upon and made payable for the several Goods and Merchandizes, and also the Tonnage and Keelage of Ships and Vessels (in the said Act particularly mentioned and expressed) for and during the further Term of Twenty-one Years, to be computed from the Expiration of the said Term granted by the said Act of the Sixth Year of her said late Majesty’s Reign: And whereas by an Act of the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Ma-10 G 3. c.14. jesty, intituled, An Act for further continuing the Duties granted and continued by several Acts made in the Sixth and Tenth Tears of the Reign of Queen Anne, and in the Seventh Year of the Reign of King George the First, for repairing the Harbour and Key of Watchett, in the County of Somerset, after reciting (among!! other Things) that it had been lately discovered, that the Term limited by the said Act of the Seventh Year of the Reign of his Majesty King George the First, for collecting such of the said Rates and Duties (the Grant whereof was temporary only) did expire on the Twenty-fifth Day of March, in the Year of our Lord One thousand seven hundred and fifty, but that through Ignorance of such Expiration the whole of the said Rates and Duties had been continued to be collected and applied as before; and after reciting that the said Harbour and Key, soon after the passing the first-mentioned Act, were repaired, and a large Pier erected at a very great and the foie Cost and Expence of Sir William Wyndham Baronet, Grandfather of George then Earl of Egremont, now George Obrien Earl of Egremont; and that the fame Harbour, Key, and Pier had ever since been repaired and supported by the said Sir William Wyndham, Charles late Earl of Egremont, and George Obrien now Earl of Egremont, Lords of the said Manor of Watchett, for the Security of the Ships and Vessels riding in the said Harbour, and the Preservation of the said Town and the Inhabitants thereof from the Inroads of the Sea, at a great annual Expence; and that it had been found by long Experience that such of the said Rates and Duties, the Grant whereof was made perpetual to the Lords of the said Manor, so long as they should repair the said Harbour, had not proved, nor were likely to be sufficient to defray the current Expences of the Repairs and other incident Charges; it was enacted, That all and every the Rates, Duties, and Sums of Money, by the said Act passed in the Sixth Year of her said late Majesty’s Reign, granted and made payable for the said Term of Twenty-one Years therein mentioned, and by the said Act passed in the Seventh Year of the Reign of his said late Majesty King George the First continued and made payable for the said further Term of Twenty-one Years computed as therein mentioned, should from and after the First Day of May in the then present 2 Year,

Year, One t'noufand seven hundred and seventy, be revived and further continued, charged upon, and made payable for the several Goods and Merchandizes; and also the Tonnage and Keelage of Ships and Vessels (in the said Act of the Sixth Year of her said Majesty’s Reign particularly mentioned and expressed) for and during the further Term of Forty Years, to be computed from the said First Day of May One thousand seven hundred and seventy, and until the End of the then next Session of Parliament: And whereas the Rates and Duties, the Grant whereof was made perpetual by the said Act paCTed in the Sixth Year of her said late Majesty’s Reign, to the Lords of the said Manor, so long as they should repair the said Harbour, have not proved, nor are by any Means sufficient to defray the ordinary Expences of the Repairs thereof, and other incidental Charges: And whereas the said Harbour is of great Use for the Security of Ships and Vessels in Distress passing to and from the Ports of Bristol and Bridgewater, and other Parts adjacent lying on the Coast: And whereas the said Pier is become so very weak and unfound in many Parts, that it is frequently subject to many Breaches from the Violence of the Sea, which there rages in an extraordinary Degree, and which, if not instantly. repaired, would inevitably endanger the whole Harbour and Pier, and the Safety of the said Town and its Inhabitants; but for all which necessary Demands no effectual Provision can be made without a constant Stock and and Supply of Money for that Pinpofe: May it therefore please Your Majesty, that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That all and every the Rates, Duties., and Sums of Money which by the said Act, passed in the Sixth Year of her said Majesty’s Reign, were granted and made payable for the said Term of Twenty<-one Years therein mentioned, and by the said Clause in the said Act passed in the Tenth Year of her said Majesty’s Reign, granted and made payable, and by the said Act passed in the Seventh Year of the Reign of his said Majesty King George the First, continued and made payable for the said further Term of Twenty-one Years, computed as therein mentioned, and by the said Act passed in the Tenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, revived, continued, and made payable for the said further Term of Forty Years, computed as therein-mentioned, shall, from and after the Expiration of the said last-mentioned Term, be further continued, charged upon, and made payable for the several Goods and Merchandizes, and also for the Tonnage and Keelage of Ships and Vessels (in the said Act of the Sixth Year of her said Majesty’s Reign particularly mentioned and expressed) for and during the further Term of Forty Years, to be computed from the Expiration of the said last-mentioned Term, granted by the said Act of the Tenth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign, and until the End of the then next Session of Parliament; ANNO QUADRAGESIMO NONO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 4.

An Act for more effectually improving the Streets, Lanes, and public Passages, in the Town of Gains-burgh in the County of Lincoln; and for laying a Duty on Coals brought to the said Town to be sold. [13th March 1809.3

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Ninth Year of the Reign of 9g.3.c. »x. His present Majesty King George the Third, intituled, An Act for the more effectual paving, cleansing, lighting and watching the Streets, Lanes, dlleys and Public Passages in the Town of Gainsburgh in the County of Lincoln; and for laying a Duty on all Coals brought to the said Town to be sold, and for applying the same to such Purposes; whereby certain Powers and Authorities were given to the Trustees therein named, and their Successors, for the several Purposes of paving, lighting, cleansing and watching the said Streets, Lanes, Alleys and public Passages within the said Town of Gainsburgh, and for removingNuifances andAnnoyances therein; and certain Duties were laid on all Coals brought to the said Town to be sold: And whereas the Trustees for executing the said Act have made great Progress in the Execution thereof, but the Duties thereby laid on Coals have pro - ed insufficient for defraying the Expences attending the fame, and a considerable Sum of Money hath been borrowed on the Credit of the said Duties which Hill remains due and owing; and it is expedient that [Lee. & Per.] * £ such

XIII. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons shall empty any Necessary-house or Bog-house at any other Time than between the Flours of Ten of the Clock at Night and Six of the Clock in the Morning, or shall wilfully spill any of the Soil of any Necessary-house or Bog-house, in any of the said Streets, Lanes, Ways, Passages or public Places, every such Person or Persons so offending shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings.

XXXIV. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That where any Question shall arise touching the Title of any Person to any Money to be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name or with the Privity of the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery, in pursuance of this Act, for the Purchase of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or of any Estate, Right, or Interest in any Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments to be purchased in pursuance of this Act, or to any Bank Annuities to be purchased with any such Money, or the Dividends or Interest of any such Bank Annuities, the Person cr Persons who shall have been in Possession of such Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments at the Time of such Purchase, and all Persons claiming under such Person or Persons, or under the Possession of such Person or Persons, shall be deemed and taken to have been lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditamen's, according to such Possession, until the contrary shall be shewn to the Satisfaction of the said Court of Chancery; and the Dividends and Interest of the Bank Annuities to be purchased with such Money, and also the Capital of such Bank Annuities, shall be paid, applied, and disposed of accordingly, unless it shall be made appear to the said Court that such Possession was a wrongful Possession, and that some other Person or Persons was or were lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments, or to some Estate or Interest therein.

XXXVI. And be it further enacted, That the Surrender or Conveyance of any such Eft ate or Interest of any Feme Covert to the said Iruftees, or any Person or Persons in Trust for them, by Indenture or Indentures, of Bargain or Sale, sealed and delivered by such Feme Covert in the Presence of and attested by Two credible Witnesses, and duly acknowledged, shall as effectually and absolutely convey the Estate and Interest of such Feme Covert in the Premises, as any Fine or Fines, Recovery or Recoveries would or could do if levied or suffered thereof in due Form of Law; and that all Bargains and Sales whatsoever to be made of any such Lands, Tenements, Buildings, and Hereditaments as shall be purchased by the said Trustees by virtue of and for the Purposes of this and the said recited Act, shall have the like Force, Effect, and Operation in Law, to all Intents and Purposes, as any Fine or Fines, Recovery or Recoveries whatsoever, would have had if levied or suffered by the Bargainer or Bargainers, or any Person or Persons seised of any Estate in the Premises, in Trust for such Bargainer or Bargainers, in any legal Manner or Form whatsoever.

XXXVII. And be it further enacted. That every Lessee or Tenant for Years or a Year or at Will, or any other Person or Persons in possession of any such Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments, which shall be purchased by virtue of and for the Purposes of this and the said recited Act, shall deliver up the Possession of such Premises to the said Trustees, or to such Person or Persons as they shall appoint to take Possession of the fame, upon having Six Calendar Months Notice in Writing from the said Trustees, or the Person or Persons so authorized by them to give the fame, at such Time or Times as shall be required by such Notice, they the said Trustees, or such other Person or Persons making such Recompence to every such Tenant or Lessee as aforesaid, in case such Tenant or Lessee shall be required to quit before the Expiration of his, her, or their Term in the Premises, as the said Trustees shall deem just and reasonable; and in case any Dispute or Difference shall arise concerning the fame, such Dispute or Difference shall be referred to the Determination of any Two Justices of the Peace (not interested in the Premises) acting in and for the Parts of Lindsey in the said County; and such Person or Persons in possession shall at such Time or Times as he, she, or they shall be required, peaceably and quietly deliver up the Possession of the said Premises to the said Trustees, or to the Person or Persons authorized by them to take Possession thereof; and in case any such Person or Persons so in possession as aforesaid, shall refuse to give up such Possession as aforesaid, then it shall be lawful for the said Trustees to issue their Precept or Precepts to the Sheriff" of the County of Lincoln, to deliver Possession of the Premises to such Person or Persons as shall in such Precept or Precepts be nominated to receive the same; and the said Sheriff" is hereby required to deliver such Possession of the said Premises accordingly, and to levy such Costs as shall accrue from the issuing and execution of such Precept or Precepts on the Person or Persons so refusing to give Possession as aforesaid, by Distress and Sale of his, her, and their Goods and Chattels.

XXXVIII. And be it further enacted, That in case any Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments to be used for the Purposes of this Act, shall happen to be in Mortgage to any Person or Persons, it shall and may be lawlul for the said Trustees, upon Application being made to them by such Mortgagee or Mortgagees, his, her, or their Executors or Administrators, and the said Trustees are hereby authorized and' required to pay such Sum or Sums of Money, after the fame shall have been so agreed for in Manner aforesaid, for such Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments in Mortgage, in Part of the Principal Money that shall be due upon such Mortgage or Mortgages, unto such Mortgagee or Mortgagees, his, her, or their Executors or Administrators: Provided always, that upon Receipt of such Sum or Sums of Money, an Indorsement shall be made upon the Back of such Mortgage or Mortgages, and signed by such Mortgagee or Mortgagees, his, her, or their Executors or Administrators respectively, in the Presence of One or more credible Witness or Witnesses, in Satisfaction of so much of the Principal Money due upon such Mortgage or Mortgages.

XXXIX. And be it further enacted, That all Sums of Money or other Consideration, Recompence, or Satisfaction to be paid or made pursuant to any such Agreement, Surrender, or Conveyance as aforesaid, or in Discharge of any such Mortgage, shall be paid or tendered to the Party or Parties entitled to the fame, or be paid into the Bank of England as aforesaid, before the said Trustees, or any Person or Persons authorized by them, shall proceed to take down any House or Houses, or other Erections or Buildings, or to make use of any Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments comprized in or affected by such Agreement, Conveyance, Surrender, or Mortgage respectively.

XL. And whereas some Part or Parts of the Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments so to be purchased as aforesaid, may happen to be more than needfary to be made use of for the Purposes of this Act; be it therefore further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, and they are hereby authorized and required to fell or dispose of, and to convey, or cause to be sold or disposed of and conveyed, such Part or Parts of the said Lands, Tenements, Buildings, and Hereditaments to any Person or Persons willing to contract, agree for or purchase the fame; and the Money arising therefrom shall be paid and applied for the Purposes of this Act.

XLI. Provided always nevertheless, and be it further enacted, That the former Proprietor or Proprietors of such Part or Parts of the fame Lands, Tenements, Buildings, or Hereditaments as may not be necessary to be made use of for the Purposes of this Act, shall have the Preference of taking or purchasing the fame, if such former Proprietors, on Notice given to them of such Intention of the said Trustees to fell, shall within Three Calendar Months agree to pay as much Money for any such Lands as shall have been or shall be offered by any other Person or Persons for the fame; and if such Proprietor or Proprietors and the said Trustees cannot agree in the Premises, the fame shall be settled by Two Justices of the Peace, not interested in the Premises, acting for the Parts of Lindsey in the said County of Lincoln.

XLII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That in case such former Proprietor or Proprietors of such Part or Parts of the said Lands, Tenements, buildings, or Hereditaments, as shall or may not be necessary to be made use of for the Purposes of this Act, shall not agree or shall refuse to purchase the fame as herein-before mentioned, any Affidavit to be made and sworn before a Master Extraordinary in the High Court of Chancery, or before One of His Majesty’s Justices of the Peace for the Parts of Lindfi y aforesaid, by some Person or Persons no way interested therein, hating that such Offer was made by or on Behalf of the said Trustees, and that such Offer was not then and thereupon agreed to, or was refuted by the former Proprietor or Proprietors respectively, to whom the fa 1 e was so offe.ed, shall in all Courts whatsoever be sufficient Evidence and Pi oof that such Offer was made and was not agreed to, or was refused by the 1 erfon or Persons to whom such Offer was made, as the Cafe may be.

XLIII. And whereas it is expedient that the Duties granted by the said recited Act on Coals brought into the said Town should be increased, and that Lime (except Lime for Manure) should be subject to the Duties herein-after mentioned; be it therefore further enacted, That, from and after the passing of this Act, for all Coals or Lime which shall be brought to any Part of the Township of Galnjburgh aforesaid, either by Land or Water Carriage, and shall be there landed or unloaded, except from one Vessel to another for the Purpose of being forwarded by Water, there shall be paid unto the Collector or Collectors, to be nominated and choien by the said Trustees in Manner herein-after mentioned, the Rates and Duties following; that is to say.

For every Chaldron of Coals containing Forty-eight Strikes, or heaped Winchester Buftiels, bond fide used for the sole Purpose of working a Steam Engine or Engines, the Sum of One Shilling:

For every like Chaldron of Coals used for any other Purpose, the Sum of One Shilling and Sixpence:

For every Ton of Coals sold by the Weight, and bondfide used for the sole Purpose of working a Steam Engine or Engines, the Sum of Eight-pence:

For every Ton of Coals sold by the Weight, and used for any other Purpose, the Sum of One Shilling: And

For every Chaldron of Lime containing Thirty-two Buftiels of heaped Winchester Measure, the Sum of One Shilling; and so in Proportion for every greater or less Quantity of Coals or Lime.

And that the said Sum and Sums of Money to be paid for such Rates or Duties as aforesaid, shall be paid by the Master or Owner or other Person or Persons having the Care or Conduct of the Ship, Boat or Vessel, Waggon, Carriage, or other Mode of Conveyance wherein or whereupon such Coals or Lime shall be shipped, loaden, carried, or conveyed, immediately after such Coals or Lime shall be delivered or unloaded from such Ship, Boat, Vessel, Waggon, Carriage, or other Mode of Conveyance respectively; any Thing in the said Act. to the contrary notwithstanding.

XLIV. And be it further enacted. That, from and after the passing of this Act, all Coals or Lime brought into any Part of the said Township as

LIII. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Trustees or any Five or more of them, and they are hereby authorized and empowered, by any Writing or Writings under their Hands, to nominate, appoint and licence such and so many Person and Persons as they shall find requisite and necessary, as Porters or Labourers for the Purpose of delivering and carrying Coals or Lime for Hire, from any Vessel or Place of Delivery upon or near the River Trent, within the Township of Gainsburgh aforesaid, into any Part of the Town of Gainsburgh aforesaid, and into any House, Outhouse, Cellar or Yard in such Town, or into any Carriage Handing in any Part of the said Town; and also to remove, suspend or displace all or any of such Porters or Labourers as they shall fee Occasion, and appoint another or others in his or their Place and Stead; and also to order, direct, regulate, settle and ascertain the Rates, Prices and Wages of such Porters or Labourers, and from Time to Time to make such Bye Laws, Rules and Orders, as to them the said Trustees shall seem necessary and expedient (such Bye Laws, Rules, and Orders, not being repugnant to the Laws of that Part of the United Kingdom called England) and to print and publish all such Rates, Prices and Wages, and also the several Orders, Rules, Bye Laws and Regulations to be made as aforesaid, by affixing true Copies thereof on the Market Place, Pump, Town Hall, or some other public Place within the said Town; and that the Names of all such Porters or Labourers so to be appointed as aforesaid, shall be entered in a Book to be kept by the Collector or Clerk for that Purpose, and he and they shall be deemed to be a Porter or Labourer, Porters or Labourers, by virtue of this Act, until he or they shall be discharged as aforesaid, or until he or they shall deliver his or their Resignation or Resignations respectively, to the said Collector or Clerk for the Time being; and that such Porters or Labourers shall be obliged to accept and take such fair and reasonable Rates, Wages and Prices, as the said Trustees or any Five or more of them, shall from Time to Time order and direct as aforesaid; and that if any of the said Porters or Labourers shall demand and receive any greater or larger Sum for such his or their Labour or Porterage as aforesaid, or shall neglect or refuse to carry Coals, or Lime, according to the Rates and Prices so to be set by the said Trustees as aforesaid, after Tender to him and them made of so much Money as shall be due, conformable to such Rates and Prices as aforesaid, every Porter or Labourer so offending shall for every 9 facn

LXXX. Provided always, and be it further enacted. That it shall be lawful for the Justice of the Peace before whom any Offender shall be convicted of any Offence against this or the said recited Act, if he shall think fit, to deduct, allow and pay any Part of the Fine, Penalty or Forfeiture which shall be imposed and received of any such Offender convicted before him of any such Offence as aforesaid, unless herein otherwise directed (not exceeding One Moiety or Half Part thereof) to the Informer or Informers, Witness or Witnesses, against such Offender, in such Shares and Proportions as to such Justice shall seem meet.

LXXXI. And be it further enacted. Rate, Assessment, Judgment, Conviction or other Proceeding, touching or concerning any of the Matters aforesaid, or touching or concerning any Offence against this or the said recited Act, shall be quashed or vacated for want of Form only, or be removed or removable by Certiorari or any other Writ or Process whatsoever, into any of His Majel-ty’s Courts of Record at Westminsier; any Law or Statute to the contrary thereof in anywise notwithstanding.

LXXXIII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That no Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall recover in any Action to be commenced against any Person or Persons for any Thing done in pursuance of this or the said recited Act, unless Notice in Writing shall have been given to the Defendant or Defendants, or left at his, her or their last or usual Place or Places of Abode Twenty-eight Days before such Action shall be commenced, of such intended Action, signed by the Attorney or Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, specifying the Cause of such Action; nor shall the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs recover in such Action, if Tender of sufficient Amends shall have been made to him, her or them, or to his, her or their Attorney, by or on behalf of the Defendant or Defendants before such Action brought, and in case no such Tender shall have been made, it shall be lawful for the Defendant or Defendants in any such Action by Leave of the Court where such Action shall depend, at any Time before issue joined, to pay into Court such Sum of Money as he, she or they shall think fit, whereupon such Proceedings, Order and Judgment, shall be had, made and given in and by such Court, as in other Actions where the Defendant is allowed to pay Money into Court.

ANNO QUADRAGESIMO NONO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

An Act for making and maintaining a Road from

Rotherham to Swinton, in the Weft Riding of the

WHEREAS the making, maintaining, and keeping in Repair z Carriage Road, from the North End of the Town of Rotherham, through Rawmarsh, to the South End of a certain Lane, tailed Pottery Lane, in the Township of Swinton, in the Weft Riding of the County of York, would be of general publick Utility, by opening a nearer and more convenient Communication between the Towns of Rotherham, Rawmarsh, and Swinton, and would be a great Advantage and Convenience to the Owners of Estates and Inhabitants in the Parishes of Rotherham and Rawmarsh aforesaid, and Wath-upon-Dearne, in the said Weft RiJing; but as the fame cannot be effected without the Authority of Parliament: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be ena&t'd; and be it enacted by the King*s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, 1 hat the Right Honourable Charles William Viscount Milton, Sir Trustees. XI. And be it further enacted, That in case any Dispute, Suit, or Litigation shall arise, touching or in anywise relating to the said Tolls, the Person or Persons appointed to collect the fame, or any other Person or Persons acting under the Authority of the said Trustees, shall not be deemed incompetent to give Evidence therein by Reason of his or their being appointed to collect such Tolls.

XII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Trustees, and they are hereby empowered, at a Meeting to be holden for that Purpose, of which Meeting One Calendar Month’s Notice shall be given in some Newspaper or Newspapers published and circulated in the said Weft Riding, and also affixed on all and every the Turnpike Gates that shall be (landing on the said Road, from Time to Time to lessen or reduce all or any of the said Tolls, and also any additional Tolls payable by any Act or Acts of Parliament now in force for Overweight, in such Manner as to them shall seem fit and convenient, for and during such Time as they the said Trustees shall think proper; and afterwards, at any Meeting to be holden as aforesaid from Time to Time, if they shall fee Occasion, to advance all or any of the Tolls so lessened or reduced to any Sum or Sums of Money not exceeding the several Rates granted by this Act, or now made payable by any Act or Acts of Parliament now in Force and Effect with respect to Overweight: Provided nevertheless, that when the whole Money borrowed on the Credit of the said Tolls shall not have been paid and discharged, such Tolls shall not be lessened or reduced without the Consent of the Person or Persons entitled to Fivedixths of the Money remaining due upon the Credit of the said Tolls.

and the said Trustees acting in the Premises shall have Power fiom Time to Time to impose any reasonable Fine or Fines on such Sheriff, his Deputy or Deputies, Bailiffs or Agents, or such Coroner, making Default in the Premises, and on any of the Persons that shall be summoned and returned on such Jury and shall not appear, unless prevented by Sickness or other sufficient Cause, or who shall refuse to be sworn on the said Jury, or on being sworn refusing to give or not giving their Verdict, or in any other Manner wilfully neglecting their Duty therein, contrary to the true Intent and Meaning of this Act; and on any of the Persons who, being required to.give Evidence before the said Jury touching the Premises, shall refute or neglect to appear, or appearing shall refuse to be sworn and give Evidence, provided that any such Fine shall not exceed the Sum of Ten Pounds upon any Inch Sheriff, his Deputy or Deputies, or Ccroner, and the Sum of five Pounds upon any other Person lor any one Offence.

and in case such Person or Persons shall be desirous of purchasing the fame, and he, flie, or they, and the said Trustees shall differ and not agree with respect to the Price thereof, then the Price or Prices thereof shall be ascertained by a Juiy in Manner herein-befoie directed with respect to disputed Value of Premises to be purchased by the said Trustees in pursuance of this Act; XXVII. And whereas a Map or Plan, describing the Line of the said Road, and the Lands through which the fame is to be carried, together with a Book of Reference, containing a Lid of the Names of the Owners and Occupiers of such Lands, have been deposited at the Office of the Clerk of the Peace for the Wed Riding of the County of York; be it therefore enatted. That the said Map or Plan and Book of Reference shall remain in the Custody of the Clerk of the Peace for the said Wed Riding, to the End that all Persons may at any feasonable 1 tines have Liberty to inspect and peruse the fame, and to take Copies or Extracts thereof at their Will and Pleasure, paying the Clerk of the Peace the Sum of One Shilling for every such Inspection, and at the Rate of Sixpence for every One hundred Words of such Copies or Extracts of the said Map or Plan and Book of Reference; and that the said Trustees, in making the said Road, shall not deviate more than One hundred Yards, of Three Feet each, from the Line described in the said Map or Plan, without the Consent and Approbation in Writing of the Person or Persons, Bodies Politick, Corporate or Collegiate, through whose Lands or Grounds such Deviation shall be made.

XXXIV. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Surveyor, or such Person or Persons as he shall appoint, from Time to Time to remove and-prevent all Nuisances and Annoyances on any Part or Parts of the said Road, by Timber, Stone, Carriages, Sawpits or other Pits, Ashes, Dung, Filth, Rubbish, or otherwise, and also to divert or turn any Watercourses, Gutters, Conduits or Drains running into the fame, to the Prejudice thereof, and to open, scour and cleanse, deepen and enlarge any Gutter, Ditch, Conduit or Watercourse adjoining or near any Part of the said Road, and also at proper Seasons of the Year to cut down, top or lop any Trees, Branches or Bullies growing in the fame Road, or in the Hedges, Fences, Banks or Grounds adjoining thereto, and to take and carry away the fame, in case the respective Owners or Occupiers of the Lands or Grounds where such Annoyances shall happen to be shall neglect so to do for Ten Days after Notice in Writing given for that Purpose under the Hands of such Surveyor, and the Charges thereof respectively (being settled by the said Trullees) shall be reimbursed from Time to Time by such respective Owners or Occupiers so neglecting as aforesaid; and in case such Charges shall not be paid on Demand, the fame shall be levied and recovered in the same Manner as the Penalties, Forfeitures, and Fines by this Act authorized to be imposed are hereinafter directed to be levied and recovered; and if, after the Removal of any such Nuisances and Annoyances as aforesaid, any Person shall offend again in like Manner, every Person so offending again, and being lawfully convicted thereof, shall forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings.

XXXV. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Surveyor, and such Person or Persons as he shall appoint, from Time to Time, without giving any previous Notice, to move all such Earth, Trees, Roots of Trees, and other Things as shall suddenly fall or be blown down from any Hedge, Bank, or Land into or upon any Part of the said Road by this Act authorized to be made or repaired, so as to narrow or obstruct the Passage along the fame, and to carry and place the fame on any Waste Ground near thereto, so as to be no Annoyance to Travellers, and such Surveyor or Surveyors shall forthwith give Notice thereof to the Owners or Occupiers of the Lands from whence such Earth, Trees, Roots or other Things, shall so Aide or fall, or be blown down as aforesaid, and the Charges of carrying away the fame (to be settled by the said Trustees) shall be reimbursed and paid to such Surveyor or Surveyors by such Owners or Occupiers, and be recovered in such Manner as the Penalties and Forfeitures for Offences against this Act are hereby directed to be recovered

XI.III. And be it further enacted. That the said Trustees shall malce or cause to be made proper Walls or Quickset Fences where necessary, as the Cafe shall require, lb as effectually to guard and fence oil the Lands adjoining to the said Road, and also proper Gates, Bridges, and Arches where necessary, out of the fame Road into the Lands adjoining, and shall keep the Quickset Fences so to be made in good Order and Repair, for the Term of Six Years from the Time that such Quickset Fences shall have been made or planted.

XLIV. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That where any particular Part or Parts of the said Road, or any Bridges, Arches, Drains, Sewers, or Watercourses, lying in and upon the fame Road, have been accustomed, or ought to be repaired and maintained by any particular Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, by reason of the Tenure of any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or by the Weft Riding of the said County of York, or any Ward, Parish, or Township therein or otherwise howsoever, all and every such Part and Parts of the said Road, and all such Bridges, Arches, Drains, Sewers, and Watercourses shall, from Time to Time be maintained and kept in Repair by such Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, County, Ward, Parishes, or Towr.ships respectively, and in such Manner as the fame ought to have been respectively maintained and kept in Repair, in case this Act had not been made.

XLV. Provided always, and be it enacted, That all Persons who by Law are liable to do Statute Work on any Part of the Roads within the Parishes, Townships, or Places through which the said Road, or any Part thereof passes, shall be liable to do the fame on the said Road; and it shall and may be lawful to and for any Two or more Justices of the Peace for the said Weft Riding of the County of York, and they are hereby required and empowered, upon Application made to them by the said Trustees, or by their Clerk or Surveyor by their Order, yearly to adjudge and determine what Part or Proportion of the Statute Work shall every Year be done upon the said Road by the Inhabitants of the respective Parishes or Places in which the said Road doth lie, and also what Proportion of the Money received by the Surveyor or Surveyors of the Highways of every such Parish or Place, in lieu of or as a Composition for such Statute Work as aforesaid, shall be by him, her, or them paid to the said Trustees or their Treasurer or Treasurers; and in order thereunto it shall and may be lawful to and for such Justices from Time to Time to summon the Surveyor or Surveyors of the Highways for every such Parish or Place to bring in Lifts before such Justices, at some Place to be expressed in such Summons (within Ten- Days after the serving of such Summons), of the Names of the several Persons who within Inch Parish or Place are by Law subject and liable to do Statute Work for that Year, or to tho Payment of any Money in lieu of or as a Composition for such Statute Work, distinguishing the Nature of the Work to be done, whether with Teams or Draughts or otherwise, and also the Amount of the respective Sums to be (o paid, which Lifts of Names shall be made in Manner, and under such Regulations and Restrictions, as is or may be directed by any Law or Statute in force and effect for the Repairs of the publick Highways; and out of such Lilts the said Justices shall and may allot, appoint, and order such and so many of the Persons who Cull appear to he subject and liable

XLVII. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees, or such Person or Persons as they shall for that Purpose appoint, are hereby empowered to contract with any Person or Persons for making, altering, raising, widening, and repairing the said Road, or any Part or Parts thereof respectively, or any Arches or Bridges upon the fame, and for doing any other Work by this Act authorized to be done, in such Manner, and for such Sum or Sums of Money as the said Trustees shall think proper, and also to contract with any Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, for the Payment of any annual Sum or Sums in gross, as a Compensation for any Loss, Injury, or Damage, which he, flie, or they shall or may sustain by carrying this Act into Execution; and all Con-tracts in Writing for any of the Purposes aforesaid, which shall be entered into pursuant to an Order made at any Meeting by the said Trustees, shall be binding to all Parties who shall sign the fame, his, her, and their Executors and Administrators; and that Actions and Suits may be maintained thereon, and Damages and Colls recovered against the Parties failing in the Execution thereof.

XLVIII. And be it further enacted. That the said Trustees shall cause the said Road to be measured, and Mile Stones and Polls to be set up, and from Time to Time renewed on the Sides thereof respectively, with Inscriptions thereon, denoting the Number of Miles and Dillance of Places, and also proper Direction Polls where any other Roads lead out of or into the fame Road; and if any Person or Persons shall wilfully break, pull down, destroy or damage any of the Stones or Polls which shall be lb fixed or set up, or eraze, obliterate, or deface any of the Inscriptions or Letters which shall be engraven or made thereon, or any Part thereof, or cause or procure the fame to be done, every Person so offending, and being lawfully convicted thereof, shall forfeit and pay a Sum not exceeding Five Pounds, at the Discretion of the Justice or Justices before whom such Offender shall be convicted.

XLTX. And be it further enacted, That if any Person shall haul or draw, or cause to be hauled or drawn upon any Part of the said Road, excepting only on crofting the fame, any Tree or Piece of Timber, or any Stone, otfierwile than upon wheeled Carriages, or shall fuller any Part of any Tree or Piece of limber, which shall be conveyed upon wheeled Carriages, to drag upon any Part of the fame Road to the Prejudice thereof, every Person so oilending, and being lawfully convicted thereof, shall forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings.

LIV. And be it further enacted. That if any Person or Persons fnalj think himself, herself, or themselves aggrieved by any Matter or Thing done in pursuance of this Act, for which no particular Relief hath been herein-before provided (save and except the Verdict of the Jury, and any Determination, Proceeding, Matter, or Thing herein-before directed to be final), such Person or Persons may, within Six Calendar Months after the Cause of Complaint {hall arise, appeal to the Justices of the Peace at their General Quarter Sessions to be holden for the Weft Riding of the County of York, such Appellant or Appellants first giving or causing to be given Twenty-one Days Notice in Writing of his, her, or their Intention to bring such Appeal, and of the Cause or Matter thereof to the Clerk or Treasurer of the said Road, and within Four Days after such Notice entering into a Recognizance before some Justice of the Peace for the said Weft Riding, with Two sufficient Sureties conditioned to try such Appeal, and abide the Order of the Justices at such Quarter Sessions, and to pay such Costs as shall be awarded against him, her, or them by such Justices, and the Justices at their said Sessions, on due Proof of such Notice having been given as aforesaid, and of the entering into such Recognizance, shall proceed in, hear and finally determine the causes and Matters of such Appeal in a summary Way, and award such Costs to the Party appealing or appealed against as they shall think proper, and their Determination therein shall be final, binding, and conclusive to all Intents and Purposes.

LV, And be it further enafied, That all Orders and Proceedings of the said Trustees, in the Execution of this A St, {hall be entered in a Book or Books to be kept for that Purpose, and shall be signed by the fame Number of Trustees as are empowered to make or direfft the fame, and shall then be deemed original Orders and Proceedings; which Book or Books, and also the Book directed to be kept for registering Mortgages and Transfers shall and may be produced and read in Evidence in all Courts and before all Justices and other Persons having Jurisdiction in the Premises.

LVI. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees may sue and be sued for or concerning any Thing which shall be done against or by virtue of this Act, in the Name of their Clerk or Treasurer for the Time being and that no Action or Suit to be brought or commenced determined by the Direction of or against the said Trustees in the Name of their Clerk or Treasurer by

LVII. And be it further enacted. That where any Distress shall be made for any Sum of Money to be levied by virtue of this Act, the Distress itself shall not be deemed unlawful, nor the Party or Parties making the same be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers on Account of any Defect or Want of Form in the Notice, Information, Summons, Conviction, Warrant of Distress, or other Proceedings 1 elating thereto, nor shall the Party or Parties distraining be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers ab initio on Account of any Irregularity which shall be afterwards done by the Party or Parties fs distraining, but the Person or Persons aggrieved by such Irregularity shall and may recover full Satisfaction for the special Damage in an Action upon the Cafe.

I, VIII. And be it further enacted, That no Order, Verdict, Assessment, Judgement, or other Proceedings made touching or concerning any of the Matters aforesaid, or touching or concerning the Conviction of any Offender or Offenders again!! this Act, shall be quashed or vacated for Want of Form, or be removed or removable by Certiorari, or by any other Writ or Process whatsoever, into any cf His Majesty’s Courts of Record at Westminster, any Law or Statute to the contrary thereof in anywise notwithstanding.

I.IX. And be it further enacted, That no Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall recover in any Action to be commenced again!! any Person or Persons for any Thing done in pursuance of this Act, unless Notice in Writing shall have been given to the Defendant or Defendants Twenty-one Days before such Action shall be commenced, of such intended Action signed by the Attorney for the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, specifying the Cause of such Action; nor shall the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs recover in any such Action if Tender of suficient Amends hath been made to him, her, or them, or to his, her, or their Attorney, by or on Behalf of the Defendant or Defendants, before such Action brought; and in case no such Tender shall have been made, it shall and may be lawful to and for the Defendant or Defendants in any such Action, by Leave of the Court after such Action shall have been brought, at any Time before Issue joined, to pay into Court such Sum of Money as he, fire, or they shall think fit, whereupon such Proceedings, Order, and Judgement shall be made and given, in and by such. LX. And be it further enacted, That no Action or Suit shall be cem-menced against any Person or Persons for any Thing done in pursuance of this Act until Twenty-one Days Notice thereof shall have been given to the Clerk or Treasurer of the said Road, nor after a sufficient Satisfaction or Tender thereof hath been made to the Party or Parties aggrieved, nor after the Expiration of Six Calendar Months from the l ime of the Fast beitjg committed; and every such Action or Suit shall be laid or brought in the County of Tvk, and not elsewhere; and the Defendant or Defendants, in every such Action, shall or may at his, her, or their Election plead specially or the General Ilfue, and give this Act and the special Matter in Evidence at any Trial to be had thereupon, and that the fame was done in pursuance and by the Authority of this Act; and if the fame shall appear to have been so done, or that such Action or Suit shall have been brought before Twenty-one Days Notice thereof was given as aforesaid, or after a sufficient Satisfaction made or tendered as aforesaid, or after the Expiration of the Time limited for bringing the fame as aforesaid, or shall be brought in any other County, then the Jury shall find for the Defendant or Defendants; and upon such Verdict, or if the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall be nonsuited, or discontinue his, her, or their Action cr Suit after the Defendant or Defendants shall have appeared; or if upon Demurrer Judgement shall be given against the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, then the Defendant or Defendants shall recover Treble Costs, and have such Remedy for the fame as any Defendant hath in other Cafes by Law.

LXI. And be it further enacted. That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others without being specially pleaded.

LXII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall commence and take place on the Second Thursday next after the passing thereof, and shall be in force and have Continuance for and during the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

Cap. 6.

An Act for enlarging the Term and Powers of Two Acts of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from Ashbourne to Sudbury, and from Sudbury to Tij.W/Bridge, and from Hatton Moor to Tutbury, in the Counties of Derby and Stafford; and for making Two new Branches of Road to communicate therewith. [13th March 1809.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Sixth Year of the Reign

of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for repairing and 6 G. 3. e. 79. widening the Road from Ashbourne to Sudbury, and from Sudbury to Yoxall Bridge, and from the Turnpike Road upon Hatton Moor to Tutbury, in the Counties of Derby and Stafford: And whereas another Act was passed in the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His said present Majesty, intituled, An Act for enlarging the Term and Powers of an. 27G.3.C.87. Act made in the Sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty King George the Third, for repairing and widening the Road from Ashbourne to Sudbury, and from Sudbury to Yoxall Bridge, and from the Turnpike Road upon Hatton Moor to 'tutbury, in the Counties of Derby and Stafford:

And whereas great Progress hath been made in the execution of the said recited Acts; for which Purpose considerable Sums of Money have been borrowed and still remain due and owing upon the Credit of the Tolls granted by the said Acts; which Money cannot be repaid, and the said Roads kept in proper Repair, unless the Term granted by the said Acts is [Lee. fit5 Per. further continued, the Tolls increased, and some of the Powers and Provisions thereof altered, enlarged, and rendered more effectual: And whereas the Road branching out of the said Turnpike Road from Sudbury to Yoxall Bridge, at or near the Village of Draycatt, in the Parish of Hanbury, and leading from thence to Stubby Lane and Foulford, and to or near the Village of Marcbington, and from thence to the Town of Uttoxctcr, and also a certain other Road branching out of the said Turnpike Road from Sudbury to Ywall Bridge, upon or near that Part of the late Forest or Chase of Necdwood which is called Hadley Plain, at the Junction of the Roads from Uttoxeter, Nctvborough, anil Hanbury, with the said T urnpike Road from Sudbury to Yoxall Bridge, and leading from thence to the Junction of the Roads from Tutbury, Burton-upon-Trent, Barton-under-Needwood, and Abbots Bromley, otherwise Pageis Bromley (all in the said County of Stafford) upon that Part of the said Forest or Chase which is called Cal-lingwood Plain, are in many Places ruinous, circuitous, narrow, and incommodious, and the making, repairing, amending, and diverting, where necessary, of the said Two Branches of Road, will be of great public Utility, and of peculiar Advantage to the Proprietors of Lands, Parcel of the said Forest or Chase, and to the Inhabitants of the adjacent Country, by affording a nearer and more convenient Communication with the Towns of Uttoxeter and Burton-upon- Trent, and divers other Towns and Places, and an easter Conveyance of Lime and and other Manure for the Cultivation and Improvement of their Lands, and for the Disposal of the Produce thereof at the neighbouring Markets: But as the fame cannot be done without the Authority of Parliament; may it therefore please Your Majesty, that it may be enatted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Conlent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the said recited Acts, and all the Clauses, Powers, Authorities, Provisions, Penalties, Forfeitures, Matters and Things therein contained (except such Parts thereof as relate to Exemption from Stamp Duties, and also such as are hereby varied, altered, or repealed) shall be and continue in full Force and Effect, and together with this present Act, shall be put in execution for and during the Term herein-after mentioned, as fully and effectually, in all Refpects and to all Intents and Purposes, as if the said Acts, and the Clauses, Powers, and Provisions therein respectively contained, were expressly repeated and re-enacted in the Body of this present Act, and as if the said new Branches of Road had been Part of the Roads included in the said Acts, but fub-ject nevertheless to the Alterations and Amendments herein contained, and which shall commence and take effect upon the passing of this Act; and that this Act and the Term and Powers hereby granted, shall be and are hereby declared to be subject and liable in Manner herein-after directed or declared, to the Payment of all Monies now due and owing, or which shall or may hereafter be borrowed or become due on the Credit of the said recited Acts and of this Act. or any of them, and of all Interest due and to become due for the fame respectively.

And be it further enacted, That if it shall at any Time be thought necessary for the better Execution of the said recited Act* or this Act, that the Trustees for either of the said Districts respectively should meet before the Time to which any Meeting of such Trustees shall be adjourned, or in case no Adjournment shall have been made, as directed by the said first-recited Act, the Person acting as Clerk to the said Trustees of such Di-strict, upon an Order in Writing signed by any Five or more of the Trustees of or for such District, (although not assembled at a meeting,) mentioning the Time and Place of such Meeting, shall, as soon as may be, give Notice thereof by Advertisement in some Newspaper printed and circulated in the Neigbourhood of the said Roads, and in such Notice appoint a Meeting of the Trustees of such District, to be held at such Time and Place as shall be directed by such Order, (such Time not beingjefs than Seven Days after Publication of the said Notice); and all the Acts, Orders, and Proceedings of the said Trustees respectively at such Meetings, shall be as valid and effectual as if such Meetings had been held in pursuance of a regular Adjournment.

VIII. And be it further enacted. That no Order or Determination made by the Trustees of either of the said Districts at any of their Meetings, shall be revoked or altered, unless at some Meeting to be held for that Purpose, of which Notice shall be given by Advertisement in some Newspaper printed and circulated in the Neighbourhood of the said Roads Fourteen Days at least before such Meeting, signifying the Occasion of such Meeting, nor unless a greater Number of Trustees shall attend at such Meeting to revoke and alter the fame than were present when such Order was made, nor then if lei's than Nine Trustees attend.

For every Horse, Mare, Gelding, Pair of Oxen, or Bullocks, or other Xolls^ Butt, drawing any Carriage whatever with W heels of lei's Breadth than Six Inches on the Sole thereof, the Sum of Sixpence:

For every Horse, Mare, Gelding, Pair of Oxen or Bullocks, or other Beast drawing any Carriage whatever with Wheels of the Breadth of Six Inches or more on the Sole thereof, the Sum of Four-pence Halfpenny:

For every Horse, Mare, Gelding, Mule, Afs, or other Beast of Burthen, laden or unladen, and not drawing, the Sum of Three Halfpence:

For every Drove of Oxen, Cows or other Neat Cattle, the Sum of Ten-pence per Score; and so in proportion for any less Number; And,

For every Drove of Calves, Swine, Sheep or Lambs, the Sum of Five-pence per Score; and so in proportion for any less Number.

XVII. And be it further enacted, That it shall and. may be lawful to and for the said respective Trustees to compound and agree with any Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, for the Statute Work to be by him, her or them done on the said Roads, or any Part thereof, and also with the Inhabitants or Occupiers of Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, of and in all or any of the Townships or Places in which the said Roads arc situate, for a certain Sum of Money, by the Year or otherwise, as the said respective Trustees shall think reasonable in lieu of the whole or any Part of the Statute or other Work to he by all or any of the said Inhabitants and Occupiers done on the said Roads,; which Composition Money shall always be paid by the Surveyor or Surveyors of the Highways, or other Officers of the Township, or by the Person or Persons so compounding, to the Treasurer to the said respective Trustees, in advance, on or before the Twenty-ninth Day of September in each and every Year, or otherwise the Inhabitants and Occupiers of such Township or Pla.ce shall not be permitted to compound for that Year.

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 7.

An Act for enlarging the Term and Powers of Two Acts of His late and present Majesty, for repairing several Roads in the Counties of Derby, Leicester, and Warwick. [13th March 1809.J

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Thirty-third Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Second, intituled.

An Act for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair several 33G.a-c.47. Roads therein mentioned, lying in the Counties of Derby, Leicester, and Warwick: And whereas another Act was passed in the Twenty-first Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for continuing the 11 G. 3. c. 91. Term and altering and enlarging the Powers of an Ail, made in the Thirty-third Year of His late Majesty, for amending, widening, and keeping in Repair several Roads therein mentioned, lying in the Counties of Derby, Leicester, and W arwick; and for amending and keeping in Repair the Road branching from Part of the said Roads between Mealham, in the said County of Derby, and Burton-upon-Trent, in the County of Stafford, to the Turnpike Road at or near the Bull’s Head Alehouse in Twycross, in the said County of Leicester:

And whereas great Progress hath been made by the Trustees appointed in or by virtue of the said recited Acts, for the Care and Management of the said several Roads in repairing and widening the fame, or such Parts thereof whereon Tollhouses and Gates have been erected, and several Sums of Money are now due and owing on the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted,

And whereas under or by virtue of an Act, passed in the Thirteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act to explain, amend, and reduce into One Act of Parliament, the General Laws now in being for regulating the Turnpike Roads in that Part of Great Britain called^England, and for other Purposes, the Trustees for the Care of particular Turnpike Roads (to whom no Powers were by the particular A fts expressly given for that Purpose) are enabled and authorized to let or farm out the Tolls arising upon such Roads, having due Regard to the several Directions contained in the fame Act for letting or farming out such lolls, but no Power or Authority is thereby given or delegated to such Trustees, so as to enable them to let or farm out the several Tolls or Duties granted and made payable by virtue of another Act, passed in the Fourteenth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for explaining and altering an Act, made in the Thirteenth Year of His present Majesty, intituled1 An Act to explain, amend, and reduce into One Act of Parliament, the ‘ general Laws nowin being for regulating the Turnpike Roads in that Part ‘ of Great Britain called England, and for other Purposes, so far as the ‘ fame relates to the Payment of additional Tolls at Weighing Engines, and ‘ the Number of Horses to be used in Carriages drawn on Turnpike Roads, ‘ and for allowing certain Exemptions with respect to Weight and Payment of ‘ Toll in particular Cafes be it therefore enacted. And be it further enacted, That in case any Dispute, Suit or Litigation shall happen to arise touching or in anywise relating to the Tolls to be collected on the said several Roads, or the Recovery of such Tolls, the Person or Persons who shall or may happen to be the Farmer or Farmers, or Renter or Renters of the said Tolls, or his, her or their Servant or Servants for the Time being, who shall or may be appointed to collect the fame, or any other Person or Persons acting by or under the Authority of the said Trullees in the Collection of the said Tolls, shall not be incompetent to give Evidence in any such Dispute, Suit or Litigation, relative to the Collection or Recovery of such l olls, whether the Payment of such Tolls shall or may happen to be enforced by Dillrefs and Sale, or by way of Information and Conviction, or by any other Ways and Means, on account of their, his or her being Farmers or Renters, Farmer or Renter of the said Tolls, or being appointed to collect the fame, or acting under the Authority of the said Trustees as aforesaid.

And be it further enacted, That when any Question shall happen to arise touching the Title of any Person to any Money to be paid into the Bank of England, in the Name and with the Privity of the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery, in pursuance of this Act, for the purchase of any Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, or of any Estate, Right or Interest in any Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments to be purchased in pursuance thereof, or to any Bank Annuities to be purchased with any such Money, or the Dividends or Interest of any such Bank Annuities, the Person or Persons who shall have been in possession of such Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments at the Time of such Purchase, and all Persons claiming under such Person or Persons, or under the Possession of such Person or Persons, shall be deemed and taken to have been lawfully entitled to such Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments according to such Possession, until the contrary shall be shewn to the Satisfaction of the said Court of Chancery; and the Dividends or Interest of such Bank Annuities to be purchased with such Money, and also the Capital of such Bank Annuities, shall be paid, applied and disposed of accordingly, unless it shall be made apparent to the said Court that such Possession was an illegal Possession, surd that some other Person or Persons was or were legally entitled to such Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, or to some Estate or Interest fherein.

XXVI. And be it further enacted. That the said Trustees may and they are hereby empowered, from Time to Time, to contract and agree with any Person or Persons for the repairing the said Roads, or any Part or Parts thereof, or for doing any other Work in the execution of the said recited Acts and this Act, in such Manner and for such Sum or Sums of Money annually or otherwise, as the said Trustees shall think proper.

For (Vcuring XXVII. And whereas Offences may happen to be committed against CiTcndm. this Act or the said recited Acts, by persons unknown to the Trustees, or to the Collectors, Surveyors or other Officers appointed to put the said recited Acts and this Act into execution; be it therefore enacted. That it shall be lawful, for the said Trustees, their Collectors, Surveyors or other Officers respectively, and such other Person or Persons as he or they shall call to his or their Assistance, without any Warrant or other Authority than this Act, to seize and detain any such unknown Person or Persons who shall commit any such Offence or Offences, and take him, her or them before any Justice of the Peace of the County or Place where the Offence or Offences shall be committed, and such Justice is hereby empow. ered and directed to proceed immediatly to the Hearing and Determination of the Complaint, or to oblige such Person or Persons so offending to give Security for his, her, or their Appearance at the next Petty Sessions to be holden within or for the County, Place or District in which such Offence or Offences shall have been committed, to answer the said Complaint; and the Justices present at such Petty Sessions or any Two or more of them, are hereby authorized and required to hear and determine the Matter of the said Complaint in a summary way, and upon Conviction of the Offender or Offenders, either by the Justice before whom he, she or they shall be first taken, or by the Justices at such Petty Sessions as aforesaid, it shall be lawful for such Justice or Justices respectively, to commit him, her or them to the Common Gaol or House of Correction of the said County or Place, there to remain for any Time not exceeding Fourteen Days, unless he, she or they shall sooner pay the respective Penalties by him, her or them incurred for such Offence or Offences, together with the Costs and Charges attendant upon such Conviction or 'Commitment.

XXIX. And be it further enacted, That no Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall recover in or be liable to sustain any Action for any Irregularity, Trespass or other Proceeding made, done or committed under or by virtue of this Act or the said recited Acts, until he, she or they shall have given or cause to have been given Twenty-one Days Notice in Writing, Hating the Ground or Cause of such Action, to the Clerk or Clerks for the Time being to the said Trustees, or after a sufficient Satisfaction of Amends or a Tender thereof hath been made by or on the behalf of the Party or Parties who shall have committed, or caused to have been committed any such Irregularity, Trespass or wrongful Proceeding, to the Party or Parties aggrieved, before the Commencement of any such Action; and in case no such Satisfaction or Tender shall happen to have been made, it shall be lawful for the Defendant or Defendants in any such Action, by leave of the Court in which any such Action may be brought or be depending at any Time before Issue joined, to pay into Court such Sum of Money as he, Ihe or they shall think fit, whereupon such Proceedings, or Order and Judgment shall be had, made and given in and by such Court, as in other Actions wherein the Defendant is allowed to pay Money into Court.

XXX. And be it further enacted, That all the Costs, Charges and Expences incident to and attending the obtaining and passing this Act, shall be defrayed, paid and discharged by the said Trustees, or any Five or more of them, out of the Monies already collected or received by virtue of the said recited Acts, or out of the first Monies to arise by virtue of the said recited Acts or this Act, in preference to all other Payments whatsoever.

XXXI. And be it further enacted. That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices and others, without being specially pleaded.

XXXII. And be it further enacted, That the said recited Acts (fub-jest to the Alterations and Amendments herein contained) and this Act, shall continue and be in Force, and be executed for and during the Residue

XXXIII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That nothing in this Act contained shall be construed or adjudged to defeat, lessen, or prejudice the Right, Title, or Interest of the Lord of the said Manor for the Time being, of, in, or to the Seignories or Royalties, Franchises, and Liberties incident and belonging to the said Manor, but the Lord of the said Manor for the Time being shall at all Times for ever hereafter have, hold, take, and enjoy all Rents, Fines, Suits, and Services, fishing, hunting, hawking, and fowling, and all Beasts and Birds considered as Game, and all other Royalties, Liberties, Privileges, Franchises, Jurisdictions, and Appurtenances whatsoever (except such as arc expressly taken away by this Act), in the fame and as ample a Manner to all Intents and Purposes as they are now held, taken, and enjoyed, or have been heretofore held, used, taken and enjoyed by the present or any former Lord or Lords of the said Manor, or as he or they or any of them might or could have held, used, exercised, and enjoyed the fame, had this Act or the said recited Act not been made.

Cap. io.

An Act for amending so much of an Act of the Forty-first Year of His present Majesty, for building and keeping in Repair the Pier at Sheerness, in the Isle of Sheppy, in the County of Kent, and for other Purposes therein mentioned, as relates to the said Pier.

[24th March 1809.]

WHEREAS an Act was made in the Forty-first Year of the Reign

His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for building a Pier at 41O.3-c.s4. Sheerness, in the Isle of Sheppy, in the County of Kent, for ascertaining, imposing, and recovering certain Duties for the supporting, maintaining and keeping in Repair the said Pier, for paving, repairing, cleansing, lighting, watching, watering and improving the Highways, Streets, Lanes, andtother public fajftges and Places within that part of the Partfh of Minster in the said Isle of Sheppy ('which iicth near his Majesty's Dock Yard and Garrison o/\Sheerness j called Blue Town and Mile Town, and for preventing Huifances, Annoyances and Obfiruclions therein: And whereas a considerable Sum of Money has been borrowed, and is now due and owing, and several Annuities have been granted upon the Credit of the Rates, Duties and Assessments granted by the said recited Act, and the Rates, Duties and Af-fefiinents granted by the said recited Act have been found inadequate to the Payment of the Interest of such Money, the said Annuities, and the necessary Charges and Expences of maintaining and keeping in Repair the said Pier;

and the said recited Act has been found in some Points defective, and if is necessary that the fame should be altered and amended j May it therefore please your Majesty, That it may be enacted; And be it enacted by the Kings most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, c and by the Authority of the same, That the said recited Act, and all and every the Rates, Duties, Clauses, Powers, Exemptions, Rules, Remedies, Regulations, Penalties, Forfeitures, Articles, Matters and Things whatsoever therein contained, as relate to the repairing and keeping in Repair the said Pier (save and except such Parts of the fame as are herein altered, varied or repealed) shall be and the fame is and are hereby declared to be in full force and efteft for carrying this Act into execution, in as full, ample, and beneficial Manner, to all Intents and Purposes, whatsoever, as if the fame had been repeated and and re-enacted in the Body of this Act.

II. And be it further enacted, That from and after the passing of this Act, all and every the Rates and Duties granted and made payable by the said recited Act, upon the Importation or Exportation, lading or unlading, taking on board or discharging at or from the said Pier of any Corn, Grain or Seeds, Beer or other Goods, Wares or Merchandize, Baggage, Parcels or Passengers, Coals, Culm, Splint, Coke or Cinder, or other Article whatsoever, shall be and the fame are hereby repealed and declared to be null and void to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever.

III. And be it further enacted, That every Mailer of every Ship, Hoy, or other Vessel, Boat or other Craft, who shall lade or unlade, take od board or discharge at or from the said Pier any Corn, Grain or Seeds, or any Goods, Wares or Merchandize, Baggage, Parcels or Passengers, passed, passing, or to pass from Port to Port within this Realm, or passed, passing, or to pass from or to any Place within the same Port wherein the Pier is situated, shall pay for every Twenty Quarters of Wheat, Meal, Rye, Barley, Pease, Beans, Tares, Mullard Seed, Canary Seed, and Seeds of every Denomination To laden or unladen there, Nine Pence j and for every Twenty Quarters of Malt or Oats, Four Pence Halfpenny, and so at and after the said Rate for a greater or less Quantity than Twenty Quarters; and for all Goods, Wares, Merchandize, Baggage, Parcels and Passengers, lb laden or unladen, taken on board or discharged at or from the said Pier, every f«ch Mailer shall pay the Sum of Sixpence in every Twenty Shillings on the Amount of the Freight upon or in regard of the Freight of all such Goods, Wares and Merchandize, Baggage and Parcels, and upon the Fare of all such Passengers, and so in proportion for every Sum less than Twenty Shillings.

IV. And be it further enacted, That every Mailer of every Ship, Hoy or other Vessel, who shall lade or unlade, take on board or discharge at or from the said Pier any Corn, Grain or Seeds, or any Beer, or any other Goods, Wares or Merchandize, or any Baggage, Parcels or Passengers, coming from or to be transported or carried to any Port beyond the Seas, shall pay in regard of his Freight, for every Twenty Quarters of Wheat, Meal, Rye, Ikrley, Pease, Beans, Tares, Mullard Seed, Canary Seed and Seeds of every Denomination, so laden or unladen there, coming from or to be transported or carried to Parts beyond the Seas, the Sum of One Shilling and One Penny Halfpenny, and so at and after the said Rate for

any

49° GEORGII III. Cap. 10.

any greater or less Quantity than Twenty Quarters; and for everyTwenty Quarters of Malt or Oats, Sixpence Three Farthings, and so at and after the said Rate for any greater or less Quantity than Twenty Quarters; and for all such Beer or other Goods, Wares and Merchandize, and for all such Baggage, Parcels and Passengers, so laden or unladen, taken on board or discharged there, coming from or to be transported or carried to Parts beyond the Seas, every such Master shall pay in regard of his Freight as aforesaid, the Sum of Sixpence in every Twenty Shillings on the Amount of the Freight.

V. And, to prevent Frauds, it is hereby enacted, That all such Mailers of Ships, Floys or other Vessels, Boats or other Craft, shall be liable to the said Duties, according to the usual Freight of each Article, and according to the usual Fare of Passengers, whether they shall respectively charge such Freight or Fare or not.

VI. And be it further enacted, That every Merchant or other Person whomsoever owning and lading or unlading, or importing or exporting, or receiving, fending or consigning by Water from or to any Port or Place in Parts beyond the Seas, or any Port or Place within the United Kingdom, or to or from any Place, Ship, Veil’d or other Craft, within the same Port wherein the said Pier is situated, any Goods, Wares, Merchandize, Baggage, Parcels or other Article whatsoever (except Coals, Culm, Splint, Coke or Cinder), at or from the said Pier, shall pay towards the Purposes of this Act the several Rates and Duties mentioned in the Table or Schedule to this Act annexed.

VII. And be it further enacted. That it shall and may be lawful to and for the Commissioners acting in the execution of the said recited Act and of this Act, or their Successors, or any Five or more of them, to ascertain and fix such reasonable Rates and Duties to be paid upon the lading or unlading, importing or exporting, or receiving, fending, or consigning by Water at or from the said Pier from or to any Port or Place in Parts beyond the Seas, or any Port or Place within the United Kingdom, or to or from any Place, Ship, Vessel or other Craft within the same Port wherein the said Pier is situated, of any Article or Commodity not specified or enumerated in the said Table or Schedule hereunto annexed (except Coals, Culm, Splint, Coke or Cinder) in proportion to the several Rates and Duties therein specified, as they shall think fit, such Rates ana Duties not being in any Cafe more than at and after the Rate of One Penny in the Hundred Weight on such Article or Commodity, which Rates and Duties, whenfo fixed and ascertained by the said Commissioners or their Successors or any Five or more of them, shall be confulered as good, valid, and effectual, to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever, as if the fame had been enumerated in this Act, or in the Table or Schedule hereunto annexed.

Cap. 11.

An Act to continue the Term, and alter the Powers of an Act of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from the Township of Saltney, in the County of Flint, to the Town of Flint. [24th March 1S09. J

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Twenty-eighth Year of

the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for re- 28 G. 3. pairing, widening, turning, and altering the Road from the c• 101 Township of Saltney, in the County of Flint, to the Town cfVWut, in the said County: And whereas the Trustees appointed in o by virtue of the said Act have made great i’rogrefs in making and repairing the said Road, and have for that Purpose borrowed a confuierable Sum of Money upon the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which (till remains due, with a conltderable Arrear of Interest, and cannot be repaid, and the said Road effectually amended, improved, and kept in Repair, unless the Term granted determined by die said Act be continued, and feme of the Powers of the said Act altered, amended, and enlarged: May it therefore pleale Your Majesty That it may be enacted, and be it enacted, by the King’s Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Content of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament alfcm-bled, and by the Authority of the same, That the said recited Act, and all the Powers, Provisions, Matters, and Things therein contained, (ex- ~rr~, n cept such as ire hereby varied, altered, or repealed,) shall be and continue Urged. Cap. i2.

An Act for making and maintaining a Road from Horsham, to join the Turnpike Road leading to Guildford, with Two Branches therefrom, in the Counties of Sussex and Surrey.

\j2.\\}n March 1809.]

WHEREAS the making, maintaining, and keeping in repair, a Turnpike Road from the Black Horse Inn, in the Town of Horsham, in the County of Sussex, to Aldfold Croffways, in the Parish of Aidfold, in the County of Surrey, to join the present Turnpike Road there leading to Guildford, with Two Branches therefrom commencing at the South-east Corner of Platters Hill Coppice; one of such Branches leading through the Parilhrs of Slindfold and Warnham to join the present Turnpike Road front Horsham to Dorking, near Kingsfold Toll Gate, in the County of Sussex; and the other Branch leading over Awfcld Dean Bridge to a Place called Park Street Corner, in the Parish of Slingfold aforesaid, would, by opening a more direct Communication between the Towns of Guildford and Horsham, and frverai other Places upon the Line of such Road and Branches, be of great Advantage and Convenience to the Land Owners and Inhabitants of the Neighbourhood and the adjacent Country, and would likewise be of public Utility: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’* most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament [Lot.
